item.title: Digital Pedagogies: A Flipped Design in the ESL -EFL Classroom
item.content:encoded:
New technologies and digital pedagogies are being used in classrooms across the globe. I performed research into the effects of new digital pedagogies, specifically the flipped learning design, in English acquisition classrooms. Articulate Rise was used to showcase this research in the form of a course/tutorial for Educators.

I have also included a link to the designs within the Articulate 360 environment so that you can have a more in-depth look at the course. Please be advised that there is no audio. Click here.
item.dc:creator: mccray.i@husky.neu.edu

item.title: CAPSTONE
item.content:encoded:
My Capstone project focused on action research in the field of English Language Learner assessment from a K-12 perspective.

The Problem of Practice Statement:

English Language Learners are often not assessed efficiently on multi-levels. Large summative tests produced outside of school, as well as classroom based assessments do not address the needs of the ESOL student population. While assessments are designed to assess what a student knows, these assessments often go beyond that purpose and test the language ability of students. This puts ESOL students at a disadvantage because of their English acquisition levels.

VIEW the research
item.dc:creator: mccray.i@husky.neu.edu

item.title: Social
Education Consultant
item.content:encoded:
Overview

Education consulting is quite popular throughout Asia. Every year, parents enlist the help of private tutors, school endorsed after-school programs, and education firms to extend the learning of their children. These firms are often reinforcers of what goes on in the classroom. My firm focused on assisting students in meeting grade-level standards as well as introducing students to higher skill levels that are not addressed in most K-12 international schools. We developed extensions of lessons with the objective to build a solid foundation in writing, debate, problem solving, and critical thinking. Interviews conducted with parents have revealed that parents want their children exceeding in English acquisition for acceptance into high-ranking boarding schools and universities abroad. In order to do this, students must first meet grade-level international standards in schools. In this capacity, I was tasked with building curricula and instructing students to meet this goal.

Importance

Independent education firms serve as a bridge between what students learn in the classroom and the more advanced skills that they can learn outside of the classroom. The education plan of a student is an integral part of their development. It encourages students to take a higher look at their trajectory and become self-regulated. It also instills in them a vigor to become life-long learners.

 

In addition, establishing student learning outcomes and evaluating evidence of effectiveness cyclically through formative AND summative assessments is important. It provides opportunities for faculty to examine what students know and the value of curriculum and pedagogy.

 

Skills

curriculum building 

needs analysis

content curation

scaffolding

differentiation

assessment

ADDIE

Impact

Students go on to meet and excel on international assessments and exams- boarding school entrances tests like the ISEE, SSAT, and HSPT; state and national assessments; and English acquisition exams like the TOEFL or IELTS. The instructional plans we developed improve performance and encouraged transfer of learning to a broad base of new situations.

Evidence

view the ADDIE Design write-up
View the e-Learning Module

Password: 2022

item.title: Organizational Change Consultant
item.content:encoded:
Project Overview

This case provided an opportunity for me to work as a consultant on several organizational problems affecting a manufacturing company. We utilized Aleckson and Ralston-berg’s framework for successful organizational collaboration. This framework revolves around organizational dynamics. The frames are political, cultural, structural, evaluative, and momentum-based. The in-class case presented our group with a company with inefficiencies in several parts of their organization. These problems revolved around collaboration and communication. This course allowed me to develop a program evaluation plan to assess strengths, weaknesses, and overall patterns of a company.

Project Details:

Intended Audience:

MI Executives

Responsibilities

Consulting, Training and Development, Organizational Change Management, Pedagogical Evaluation, SME Collaboration

Team:

3 Instructional Designers

Importance

Solutions to this organization’s problems were embedded in the establishment of what we’re doing, how we’re doing it, and why we’re doing it. We establish project values, goals, a road map, and the major milestones of a project. We establish the specific roles, their important functions, expectations and action plans. We establish a shared language and base knowledge of the content so that meaning is conveyed from one party to the next. We establish the working theory, pedagogy, and development models that inform our design. We establish company-specific communication protocols and procedures. 

Skills

Training Program Development

Consulting

SME Collaboration

Creative Problem Solving

Negotiation

Organizational Change Management

Formative Evaluation

AGILE Model

Organizational Change

Impact

We were able to recommend to several executives an action plan for successful knowledge transfer and training of their staff. This establishment process, in general terms, lays the groundwork for successful communication and micro-collaboration in terms of knowledge management transfer from SMEs to current staff and new hires.

Evidence

item.title: Project Manager
item.content:encoded:
Project Overview

Northeastern University will evaluate the current e-Learning and Instructional Design program within the College of Professional Studies. This short-term project will conduct the background research necessary to support a program needs assessment and proposal to update the concentration. This serves as the background work for the business case and the Project Sponsor will utilize the data to propose a curriculum and name change to the e-Learning and Instructional Design program. The sponsor has asked for research into the modern duties of an instructional designer and learning experience designer.

Success Criteria:

This project will be successful if the business case is approved and new development of courses and curricula begins.

This project will be successful if it increases the number of inquiries and enrollments in classes as well as the satisfaction surveys of those enrollees.

This project will be successful if it meets ROI goals and other financial measurements.

This project will be successful if deliverables are completed on time and run professionally according to the project sponsor’s needs.

Project Details:

Project Title:

eLearning and Design Program and Planning Research
Project Dates:

September 29, 2019 to December 8, 2019
Project Coordinators:

Micky M. and Elizabeth G.

Approach

As we analyze, our intention is to encode current job descriptions in order to find common key words, themes, competencies, skills, and experience within each description. The focus of our research is to answer the question, “What are current employers looking for in a modern Instructional Designer?”.

We will compile numerical data in order to illustrate the most important competencies, skills, and experience required by employers. We will compile data that illustrates aligned competencies across industry organizations.

We will also analyze other graduate level programs who are offering comparable instructional design and e-learning programs utilizing a SWOT analysis. We will determine if they are meeting the expectations of the current job market. We will look for similarities and differences within the programs as well as niche opportunities that competitive Universities provide for their students. We will compare these programs with that of Northeastern’s and provide recommendations for change.

We will compile this data into comprehensible tables that can be used later in presentations for key stakeholders.

Importance

With this information, the College of Professional Studies will be able to review their competitive advantage and implement any changes to the program that will benefit the school and provide a more marketable course of study. There are multiple stakeholder who will benefit from the redesign of the program: future students, College of Professional Studies, leadership (Dean, Asst. Dean), and faculty. 

Skills

Market Research

Leadership

Content Research

Project Management

Needs Assessment

Program Planning

Program Assessment

Organizational Development

Impact

Northeastern University is retiring the eLearning and Instructional Design program and launching the Master of Professional Studies in Learning Experience Design and Technology. This program encompasses more technical skills that competitor university offers.

Evidence

View The Project Charter

item.title: Work
Assessment Plan Evaluation
item.content:encoded: Establishing student learning outcomes and evaluating evidence of effectiveness cyclically through formative AND summative assessments is important. It provides opportunities for faculty to examine what students know and the value of curriculum and pedagogy. I completed an evaluation of an assessment plan at the collegiate level. This allowed me to see how departments at the University level gauge success. My partner and I focused on the Master of Sports Leadership program at Northeastern University.

item.title: Networked Classroom
item.content:encoded:
Overview

How People Learn is about evidence-based pedagogical theory. There are two inputs of the learning process - instructional inputs and student inputs. The instructional inputs of modeling, practice opportunities, motivation, powerful feedback tools, and metacognitive strategies for students assist them in becoming experts. Student's intrinsic motivations, beliefs, and prior knowledge that they bring to the learning process can help or hinder the learning process. eLearning designers should teach deep structural competence or pattern recognition, as well as emphasize the what, how, when and why of the subject matter (Bransford, Brown, & Cocking). I evaluate the course, Basic Management of Wounds, based on various learning theory such as Mayer’s Multi-Media Design Principles.

View the Analysis of an E-Learning Module

Password: 2022

item.title: Intro
item.content:encoded: Michigan State University

item.title: Introduction
item.content:encoded:
Overview

Each year we implement several instructional courses for Year 1 students at Michigan State University. Each course is a project. This year we introduced a new instructional design model to the college.

The Veterinary medical college has recently undergone a curriculum reinvention whereby courses are now systems-based rather than discipline-based. “Instead of having classes in basic disciplines like microbiology, the curriculum has been revised to integrate disciplines into organ systems like cardiology” (CVM, 2021).

I am the instructional designer for Year 1 students, and I oversee the building of 13 courses that are either blended, fully in-person, or fully asynchronous online.

Each course includes a team:

Faculty:

3-10 Medical Doctors
Instructional Designer:

There is one instructional designer per course.
Curriculum Content Specialists:

There are two content specialists that are responsible for coordinating and integrating disciplines horizontally and vertically across courses and the curriculum.
Technologists:

There is one Curriculum Assistant who inputs content into the D2L Learning Management System and several members of IT to assist in the facilitation of in-person lecture technology and problems that may arise from Microsoft TEAMS and D2L.

Admin Staff:

Administrators assist with scheduling labs and simulations for students.

item.title: Analyze
item.content:encoded:
Analyze

To inform our needs analysis, we use the course-end report, course summary evaluation, OSCQR design rubric, and the student evaluations from the last iteration of the course. The course-end report includes self-reflections of faculty on the facilitation of the course, the students and the goals of the course for the following year. There are 5 major topical areas that the faculty reflect on in the course-end report – Course Improvement Goals from the last term of the course, Instructional Model, Student Performance, Content Alignment, and Course Reflection and Goal Setting for the next term of the course. The course summary evaluation includes several suggested course changes from the College Curriculum Committee. The OSCQR design rubric is used to improve the quality and effectiveness of the fully online and blended courses that we facilitate. The student evaluations, also, assist in defining course gaps and learning needs.

  • The learning context involves, in most cases, daily practice labs, lectures, and in-class learning activities. The University uses the flipped learning approach and students apply concepts they’ve learned daily from 8 am to 5 pm. The performance contexts, or where the learner will use the skills and knowledge after instruction, resemble mid-term exams, final exams, lab exams, cases and simulations that are summative in nature. The idea is to match the learning context closely with the performance context.

  • A major goal of the University with the curriculum change is to improve curriculum alignment, removing ballooning content and ensuring there are no organizational gaps across Year 1 thru Year 3. The main problems we see are that students are unable to transfer the understanding of foundational concepts learned in Year 1 to a broad base of new situations in the clinical/internship phase of Year 3. So, the instructional plan we’ve developed will improve the understanding of foundational concepts and the subsequent application of that knowledge to cases, simulations, and accompanying authentic assessments that students work on in Year 1.

  • Based on the needs, the university will produce several courses that fall under three categories - face-to-face, blended, or fully online asynchronous experiences. In addition, the University employs micro-courses – two-week courses, three-week courses, and longitudinal courses that span 15 weeks.

    Example of the Terminal Instructional Goals or Course Goals:

    After successfully completing this course, Year 1 Veterinary students will be able to:

    Identify significant normal macroscopic and microscopic structures of the musculoskeletal system in live animals, cadavers, diagnostic and microscopic images.

    Describe the clinically important functions and structure-function relationships of the musculoskeletal system and any important interaction of the musculoskeletal system with other body systems.

item.title: Design
item.content:encoded:
Describe the development of the integument system.

  • Identify the germ layers from which the components of the skin are derived.
  • Describe the general migration pathway of melanoblasts to the skin.
  • Describe the pathogenesis of two diseases that result from aberrations in the migration pathway.

Utilizing your eyes and hands, identify the gross features of the skin of domestic species.

  • Recognize how hair coats vary between species.
  • Name the areas where thick skin, grossly, can be found in domestic species.

Utilizing a microscope, identify the histologic features of the skin of domestic species.

  • Name the areas where thick skin, microscopically, can be found in domestic species.
  • Identify the epidermis and dermis of the skin within a microscopic slide or image.
  • Identify a melanocyte within a microscopic slide or image.

item.title: Develop
item.content:encoded:
Develop

The daily (or weekly) modules are created using D2L.

Our courses use the following tools :

  • Manipulatives/Real Objects – ex. Bone Boxes distributed to students

    iClicker is used for real-time recall opportunities and class discussions.

    For Lab Exam Grading, we use Scantrons that are processed by the scoring Office.

    Anatomy, Radiology, and other disciplines use SketchFab and Thinglink.com for student visuals

    PowerPoint for lectures.

  • Role Play and group problem-solving situation (Learning and Assessment Center)

    Live Video Streaming is facilitated via MediaSpace and D2L

    Google Docs, MediaSpace, and the LMS are used for online collaboration and the sharing/publishing of group presentations.

    Cases and simulations in the courses are made with PowerPoint, Captivate, and third-party computer based medical modules.

    Anatomy, Radiology, and other disciplines use SketchFab, Thinglink.com for student visuals

    Narrated Lectures are created via Kaltura, Camtasia, and PowerPoint.

    Surveys and other formative assessments are developed via D2L and Qualtrics. - Assessments are developed using ExamSoft.

    Zoom is used for Blended instruction.

item.title: Implement
item.content:encoded:
Implement

  • The University follows a framework close to the ADDIE framework. This framework elicits and establishes the project tasks, deliverable specifications, and schedule milestones, roles and responsibilities, as well as communications protocols. As I am the Instructional Designer for Year 1, I monitor the progress of each course and illustrate the critical path of the project using Microsoft Teams, Microsoft Flow, and Excel for time management and production tasks and their deliverables. For each task and its deliverable, we estimate a time required and identify a start and end date.

    Each course is developed over the course of 5 months and times are adjusted based on Faculty schedules. We collaborate by using the Microsoft TEAMS shared platform. It allows all employees to access, collaborate, and manipulate the course design.

  • Early in the design process, Instructional designers meet with the course moderator to establish quality standards, guidelines, and policies around the instructional design. The OSCQR design rubric and its standards help the course team and instructional designer to measure quality of the course.

    For students with disabilities, the Instructional Designer and Technologists modify course content manually or automatically using different software. All course content is required to meet accessibility standards as mandated by law.

  • All instructional materials are checked by Faculty, Technologists, and Instructional Designers. A final review and approval meeting are scheduled before launch to facilitate a usability and feasibility check. This ensures that content is functional and rolled out to students at the appropriate time. Assessments in ExamSoft receive several pilots to ensure that supports and accuracy are present. The reviewers check for appropriate student modifications / accommodations; standards, outcomes, assessment, and strategy alignment; project scope, content, etc. (Larson & Lockee, 2013). With the inclusion of the review, the module should be ready for students four weeks prior to the initial launch.

item.title: Evaluate
item.content:encoded:
Evaluate

  • All first-year students receive a pre-test prior to the start of a new school year (or term) during student orientation. Pre-Tests are informal, ungraded, and used to access prior knowledge and assist students with self-regulation. These pre-tests normally include a refresh on general chemistry, general biochemistry, genetics, and molecular biology, and basic statistics and scientific reading comprehension. Pre-tests are also used, in some courses, to measure learning.

    The formative evaluation plan across all courses in Year 1 include short surveys, daily prep quizzes, and formative assignments. The short surveys are completed every day or every module and allow students to give feedback to instructors on whether they were able to succeed with the learning objectives and if the instruction of the day was easily navigable and understandable. The quizzes draw a picture for the instructor of whether students understand new concepts given each day. The quizzes give the instructor the ability to make adjustments to the lesson plan immediately, like including additional scaffolding.

    As part of their summative assessment plan, students are evaluated using a mid-term and a final exam. For more authentic assessments, students are evaluated on cases and simulations using tailored rubrics.

  • After the completion of the course, a debriefing session with the course moderator is performed where we fill out a new course-end report and elicit ideas on the “grows and glows” of the course. A summary of the issues and successes are compiled by the Instructional Designer and subsequent themes are analyzed. Next, new goals are created based on the most recent iteration design and the next design will be updated to reflect the issues and concerns. Finally, student evaluations are sent out to elicit the review and assessment of their course.

item.title: Design-01
item.content:encoded:
Instructional Strategies

After introducing foundational concepts, Faculty take less of a lead as students start grappling with real-world tasks and authentic situations. A few of instructional strategies we use are:

  • Advanced Organizer/Study Guides
  • Case-Based Learning
  • Jigsaw I & II
  • Reciprocal Teaching
  • Scenario-Based Learning
  • Think-Pair-Share
  • Simulations
  • Cognitive Apprenticeship

After identifying the outcomes and strategies, we diagram or outline the daily or weekly module with the day’s resources, learning activities/strategies, and assessments. Next, we implement curriculum mapping which involves aligning those outcomes to learning activities and assessments.

item.title: Design-00
item.content:encoded:
Design

Learning Objectives

We look at the content and pre-requisites as seen across the governing boards of Veterinary medicine and unpack the college competencies. We use the competencies and course goals in conjunction with Bloom’s Taxonomy to craft learning objectives that build up to the course goals and competencies. The learning objectives are then broken down into main learning objectives and enabling learning objectives and the content is chunked into manageable daily (or weekly, modular) information and skills that students need to know or be able to do. See below for an example:

item.title: Intro
item.content:encoded:
I am a Learning Designer.

I AM AN INTERNATIONAL EDUCATOR. I became an international educator by embarking on a teacher’s certification program and relocating to Asia to work with ESOL students hoping to improve their academic writing in order to gain entrance into US boarding schools and universities. My experience abroad gave me the opportunity to develop curriculum and curate content. I use my training as a K-12 ESOL teacher to design learning around a broader range of student needs. ESOL support strategies are good practice and teaching for ALL students, not just English Language Learners.

Adult learning and eLearning development was a natural progression from my K-12 experience and education. I have a love of education and technology. I was drawn towards eLearning and instructional design because of my ability to observe how engaged learners become once quality objectives are created and technology is utilized in the classroom. Technology helps students take ownership of their own learning. The role I’ve chosen advocates for education and technology as a “great equalizer.” Being a part of this field, requires a belief that, for the next generation, education and technology will be accessible to all students and will provide equity for all groups. Global citizenship is what I strive for and what I believe is a requirement of an equity-oriented educator.

My goal is to be at the forefront of designing education solutions that will be accessible to all people, especially in developing countries. I am passionate about putting my creative side to work and bringing rich and engaged user experience to young students and adults. I ultimately aspire to help a variety of different people and cultures – whether in the Middle East, Atlanta or anywhere my ability and the opportunities afforded take me.

item.title: Strengths
item.content:encoded:
Strengths

Innovative Designs

I pride myself on creating designs that are engaging and pedagogically sound. I enjoy applying learning theory and design models that fit the learning and environmental context. I have a wide breadth of teaching and designing across all ages, content, and English-level proficiency. I have risen to the occasion and applied my organizational skills to my advantage by creating my own brand and style of innovative designs for my learners.

Creative Problem Solver

As a teacher, you are equipped with a plethora of strategies to address different learner needs. My K-12 experience transferred well into adult learning design. My process involves focusing on a given problem and employing situational awareness. I enjoy using my creativity to design with all students in mind. I use a consultative approach to develop and implement plans.

Contextual Cognizance

I consider myself an Educator who is contextually cognizant in the field of learning design. Understanding the needs of an organization is an important skill of a learning designer. I analyze strengths, weakness, and opportunities within the environment and build out strategies from the given information. I aspire to understand the perspectives of the participants in the design process as well as the organizational culture.

item.title: Education
item.content:encoded:
Education

  • Georgia State University, Atlanta

    Bachelor of Business Administration, Marketing

    Northeastern University, Boston

    Master of Education, eLearning & Instructional Design

  • K-12 Teacher’s Certification, Concentration: English to Speaker of Other Languages (ESOL)

item.title: Skills
item.content:encoded:
Competencies

Project Management K-12 SME Collaboration Program Assessment Curriculum Development Pedagogical Evaluation eLearning Development Consulting

  • ADDIE

    Understanding By Design

  • D2L

    Canvas

    Google Classroom

    SeeSaw

  • Articulate 360

    Captivate

item.title: Call to Action
item.content:encoded: Resume provided upon request

item.title: Portfolio
item.content:encoded:
Managing a Northeastern University Project

Northeastern University will evaluate the current e-Learning and Instructional Design program within the College of Professional Studies. This short-term project will conduct the background research necessary to support a program needs assessment and proposal to update the concentration.

Learn more

Designing Innovative Curricula for ESOL Students

Education consulting is quite popular throughout Asia. Every year, parents enlist the help of private tutors, school endorsed after-school programs, and education firms to extend the learning of their children. These firms are often reinforcers of what goes on in the classroom. My firm focused on assisting students in meeting grade-level standards as well as introducing students to higher skill levels that are not addressed in most K-12 international schools.

Learn more

Learning Cultural Competency through a MOOC

We live and work in diverse settings facilitated by technology that increasingly allows frequent communication and collaboration between employees and students across the globe. This MOOC guides participants in obtaining a culturally sensitive and aware skillset for navigating diverse environments.

Learn more

Promoting Organizational Change through Collaboration

This conceptual case provided an opportunity for me to work as a consultant on several organizational problems affecting a manufacturing company. We utilized Aleckson and Ralston-berg’s framework for successful organizational collaboration. This framework revolves around organizational dynamics - political, cultural, structural, evaluative, and momentum-based. I developed an evaluation plan to assess strengths, weaknesses, and overall patterns of a company.

Learn more

item.title: Addie-write-up-intro
Overview
item.content:encoded:
Overview

The purpose of this project is to design an instructional module within our international language school in Asia. The language school is spread out over 5 cities in Asia- Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen, Hong Kong, and Seoul. Every year, parents enlist the help of private tutors, school endorsed after-school programs, and language centers to extend the learning of their children. Language schools are often reinforcers of what goes on in the classroom. Our center focuses on both higher skill levels that are not addressed in most schools and the extension of K-12 lessons with the objective to bring students up to grade-level standards. Interviews conducted with parents have revealed that parents want their children exceeding in English acquisition for acceptance into high-ranking boarding schools and universities abroad. In order to do this, students must first meet grade-level international standards in schools and go on to excel on international assessments and exams.

Project Details:

Intended Audience:

5th through 6th grade traditional students with ages ranging from 9-11 years old
Responsibilities:

Instructional Design, eLearning Development
Tools Used:

DIGIcation Web Design Software, Google Apps, PlayPosit Interactive Tool, Screencast-O-Matic

item.title: Analyze
item.content:encoded:
Analyze

After an in-depth review of student interviews, in-class observations, and assessments, we’ve analyzed our learner. The module focuses on fifth through sixth grade traditional learners with ages ranging from 9-11 years old. They come from various types of schools like international schools, private schools, and Chinese public schools. Holistically, their prior knowledge varies greatly and requires differentiation and scaffolding in the design. There is a range of students who have seen various writing strategies and for some this is their first encounter with writing strategies. Prerequisite-wise, students have a grasp of the art of storytelling from earlier grades in shorter, more succinct scenarios. As they grow, they begin to flesh this out and focus on extending their writing and including descriptive details that connect to the reader.

  • The course is designed to increase their English writing strategies and applications in various performance contexts. The instructional plan we’ve developed will improve performance and encourage transfer of learning to a broad base of new situations – boarding school entrances tests like the ISEE, SSAT, and HSPT; state and national assessments; and English acquisition exams like the TOEFL or IELTS.

  • The vast spectrum of schools that students attend produce very different standards and subsequent skillsets in the four essential skills of English acquisition: listening, speaking, reading, and writing. The problem is clear; students do not meet grade-level English acquisition standards from an American or European perspective. Most students are advanced speakers and listeners; however, most students fall below the intermediate level in writing and reading.

  • Because a vast number of students will be applying to schools in the Western region, the resulting need is a design which incorporates American and European standards into its curriculum.

    Terminal Instructional Goal :

    After successfully completing the course, fifth – sixth grade students will be able to organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally in a personal narrative writing piece using the Narrative ARC.

item.title: Design
item.content:encoded:
Design

For the purpose of this course, students should focus on the creation of their own personal or fictional narrative storyline, applying the narrative arc elements of exposition, conflict, rising action, climax, falling action, and resolution. The module can be facilitated as a blended or full face-to-face 3-part learning experience. Each lesson will be a two-hour class session designed to map out the event sequences in narrative stories. Prerequisites from the Common Core Standard, The Common European Framework, and WIDA Standards inform the content as follows:

  • Orient the reader by establishing a situation and introducing a narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally.
  • Use dialogue and description to develop experiences and events or show the responses of characters to situations.
  • Use a variety of transitional words and phrases to manage the sequence of events.
  • Use concrete words and phrases and sensory details to convey experiences and events precisely.
  • Provide a conclusion that follows from the narrated experiences or events.

  • At the end of this learning module, students should be able to:

    Using a graphic organizer, identify the elements of the Narrative Arc in an animated short story.

    While working in groups, build a list that describes a strong narrative story given specific categories of performance.

    Using the given performance criteria, analyze the quality of a narrative piece.

  • To view our instructional strategies and the overall design, please click below to see the lesson plan.

    I’ve used Gagne’s Nine Events of Instruction as a lesson planning design model.

Lesson Plan

item.title: Develop
item.content:encoded:
Develop

The module will be created using two programs - Web Authoring tool Digi[cation] and Google Classroom. Google Drive is used to allow all employees of the company to access, collaborate, and use the design in offices across Asia. In addition, the course was built within a website and a learning management system for blended or hybrid use, as well as individual facilitation.

Our course uses the following tools:

Web Authoring tool Digication

Google Apps

PowerPoint for Direct Instruction

Animated video(s) through Video Sharing Platforms

Screencasting

PlayPosit interactive instructional tool for formative quizzes

Paper visuals and Graphic Organizers

item.title: Implement
item.content:encoded:
Implement

  • A review and approval log for editors and other stakeholders will be provided along with a Gantt chart illustrating start and end dates. This will ensure that the lessons are rolled out at the same time across Asia. The timeline will be efficient and streamlined. The development of the full design with all three parts should take no more than one week. With the inclusion of the review and prototype testing, the module should be ready for students four weeks after the initial phase of the ADDIE Model.

  • Our students are English Language Learners, so there are accommodation issues that must be addressed in the design. Scaffolds and modifications have strategically been placed in the design by creating both a “higher” and “lower” skilled lesson plan. A decrease/increase in learning tasks, modification of the given narrative to easier vocabulary and verb usage, decrease/increase in the time table are all acceptable accommodations. A list of appropriate ELL accommodations should be distributed in case teachers run into problems in the classrooms with students.

  • The formative evaluation plan will include a short survey, completed after every lesson, that will allow students to tell the instructor if they were able to hit the objectives. This gives the instructor the ability to make adjustments to the lesson plan immediately, like including additional scaffolding. Student Rounding is included in the lesson plan and involves descriptive feedback during instructor observations of learning tasks, as well as communication to students on how well they are doing and what areas need improvement.

    All instructional materials will be checked by SMEs, editors, and department managers and leads in each individual office across Asia (Larson & Lockee, 2013). The review board should be checking for appropriate modifications / accommodations; standards, outcomes, assessment, and strategy alignment; project scope, content, etc. (Larson & Lockee, 2013). Testing the prototype is recommended but not required due to time constraints. Instructors can test the instructional materials in one-on-one tutoring sessions by assessing the reading complexity (directions, organizers, etc.), need for visuals and organizers, time sufficiency, content appropriateness, etc.

item.title: Evaluate
item.content:encoded:
Evaluate

  • All students receive a pre-test prior to the start of a new school year (or term) or entry into the language center. Pre-Tests are informal, ungraded, and used to access prior knowledge and skill sets. These pre-tests normally include a reading passage and comprehension questions, grammar, and a writing prompt.

    As part of their summative assessment, students will be evaluated on the final draft of their narrative story. It is a formal alternative assessment; moreover, it is graded according to the distributed rubric. Towards the end of the semester, parents will receive a detailed progress report detailing their child’s improvement from the beginning of the semester to the end and a conference is scheduled to elicit opinions of the course and its effect on the student.

  • A debriefing session with the entire Asia team and other stakeholders (ex. SME) is expected. A survey will be elicited. A summary of the issues raised should be compiled by each office first and subsequent themes should be explored. Next, a formal e-mail should be sent out regarding how the old design and subsequent design will be updated to reflect the issues and concerns.

item.title: Call to Action
item.content:encoded:
VIEW THE WEBSITE

Password: 2023

My Google Class Code: 7cmjzfi

item.title: Intro-Course
Overview-course
item.content:encoded:
Overview

We live and work in diverse settings facilitated by technology that increasingly allows frequent communication and collaboration between employees and students across the globe. This course is designed as a MOOC and guides participants in obtaining a culturally sensitive and aware skillset for navigating diverse environments. There are several MOOCS that address cultural competence in terms of specific cultures, perspectives, and locations. This course looks at cultural competence from a more general lens and it caters to those looking to work abroad.

Project Details:

Intended Audience:

Individuals looking to work and study abroad.

Responsibilities:

Instructional Design, eLearning Development
Tools Used:

Canvas Learning Management System

item.title: Analyze-course
item.content:encoded:
Analyze

To inform our needs analysis, we take into account the current beliefs, attitudes, biases, and overall prior knowledge of our learners by measuring the various aspects of cultural dispositions. For example, learners are required to take an implicit bias test designed by Harvard University and measure their current dispositions according to general categories of cross-cultural dispositions. This course requires learners to eventually set goals to improve and maintain the highest level of cultural competence for their employment and studies abroad. It is assumed that the background knowledge of most students is spread out over a spectrum.

  • The learning contexts are facilitated in group settings where we create a community of inquiry. Students interact with their peers through discussion boards to create shared meaning about the topics. Next, we move towards students creating networks. We have introduced several international blogs and experts on working and living abroad and we encourage the learners to join and interact with these communities on social media platforms and others.

    This course can be used as a preemptive course to HR topics for companies with employees that will be leading diverse teams and/or moving abroad for their duties in the future. Universities with students looking to study, intern, and work abroad can facilitate this course prior to study abroad opportunities.

  • Employees and students lack the skills and attitudes they will need to work effectively in the global workplace. These organizations across the globe hope to employ individuals who strive for the highest level of cultural competence, global citizenship. Yet, many organizations face challenges when implementing Diversity and Equity initiatives and training their employees for work in diverse environments.

  • The course is intended to define a set of global competencies that students and employees will need; implement activities that will help students develop cross-cultural competence in a meta-cognitive and self-directed way and measure the degree to which these individuals will possess the requisite skills and dispositions that have been identified as important (Deardoff 2011; Fantini 2009; Lohmann, Rollins, and Hoey 2006).

    Terminal Instructional Goal

    Participants of this course will pursue a life-long goal of the highest level of cultural competence, global citizenship. Global citizenship describes “a desire to help or work with people from different countries to solve cross-cultural or global problems” (Davies, et al., 2015, p.83).

item.title: Design-course
item.content:encoded:
Design

This is an introductory, modular, free, and open-to-enrollment mini-MOOC. The networked learning environment is fully asynchronous, student-led and Instructor facilitated.This course is best facilitated in a group. There are two modules in this course and the Life Cycle of the course is projected to be 3 -7 years.

Course Learning Objectives

  • Identify a list of global/cultural competencies that are necessary for those wanting to work abroad.
  • Practice value-based discussions around diversity and cultural competence.
  • Evaluate your current skills and develop a plan to progress towards your desired professional cultural competence.

item.title: Develop-course
item.content:encoded:
Develop

This course was developed using the Canvas Learning Management System.

This course uses the following tools:

  • Slideshare

  • Multiple Video Sharing websites - YouTube, TED Talks

  • Multiple Social Media platforms and Blogs

item.title: Implement-course
item.content:encoded:
Implement

  • Because this is a MOOC, we've reused, revised, remixed, and redistributed several Open Educational resources surrounding the topic while also encouraging students to add their own curated information to the mix. Resources are free and open to students with the appropriate attribution to original creators.

  • The course took 4 weeks to go through the process of analyzing our learner, designing the course, developing the course, and implementing and evaluating. The analysis, design, and development of the course took two weeks. The course was tested and piloted with students and other Instructional Designers as well as fully launched and evaluated for an additional two weeks. During those 4 weeks, my partner and I developed a sequence of tasks that can be carried out concurrently, assigning those tasks to each other, student testers, and other instructional designers. Milestones were checked by the Project Champion and the ultimate deliverables were submitted to the Project Sponsor.

  • A usability and feasibility test was implemented by students and other Instructional Designers to verify that the instruction operates correctly and meets the content and functionality specifications.

    The following questions were addressed during these tests:

    1. What is your understanding of the MOOC’s intended outcomes (what it is designed to accomplish)?

    2. How does what you gained compare with your understanding of the intended outcomes?

    3. How challenging was the work? Did it stretch you, and if so in what ways? Was it too easy, and if so what recommendations do you have for increasing the rigor? Was it too much, and if so what are your recommendations for paring back?

    4. How much time did it take for you to do the assigned work? How did that compare with your expectations for the amount of time it would take?

    5. What is your perception of the quality of the OERs included in the MOOC and the MOOC author’s decisions about what to provide (quality of curation)?

    6. What is your perception of the quality of the original materials created by the MOOC author?

    7. What was your experience carrying out the MOOC assignments? What are your recommendations for improving the clarity of the assignment? What are your suggestions for improvement (e.g., thoughts on revising, enhancing, or augmenting the MOOC)?

    8. How did the MOOC engage you as a learner (questioning, viewing/reading, experimenting or practicing, creating, reflecting, synthesizing learning)? What recommendations do you have for improving learner engagement?

    9. In what ways did the MOOC take advantage of the online format (images, video, hyperlinks, interactive components)? What are your recommendations for improvement?

    10. What was your experience navigating the MOOC? What are your recommendations for improving the course layout and organization of materials? Were there any barriers to navigation? Note things like broken links, missing pages, etc.

item.title: Evaluate-course
item.content:encoded:
Evaluate

Assessment of Student Learning

In module 1, There are two discussion board posts where students will collaborate to make meaning about the content. The first discussion board post is an introduction where students are asked to describe their goals for international work. The second discussion board asks students to relate their new knowledge with the tests that they took with Harvard and think about where they are with the competencies that describe a truly culturally competent international worker. They are asked to provide background information about their personal lives and upbringing which may contribute to their current levels of cultural competence.

In module 2, the first formative Assessment is a discussion board post where students will engage in those external learning environments and bring back big ideas to the group on what they’ve observed in Facebook groups and International blogs. The second formative Assessment is a discussion board post to brainstorm ideas on how students will plan to increase their desired cultural competencies. This is an opportunity to receive feedback from their peers. This rolls them directly into their summative assignment.

At the end of the course, students will take what they have learned from the course and write a summative, evaluative paper planning ways they will increase their cultural competency. Again, this brings us back to the self-directed learning piece where students set goals and action to achieve those goals.

item.title: Call to Action
item.content:encoded:
View the course

Use the following join code: 4MRJNJ

item.title: Design-01-course
item.content:encoded:
Instructional Strategies

In this course, students learn utilizing the Connectivist Approach. Students learn by making connections to external content and looking for like-minded interest groups, in addition to traditional content, in order to benefit from the work of others. 

In this online environment the instructor should engage with the students on their discussion posts. Providing feedback and correcting common misconceptions. When experts and groups of learners are not together, students miss the effects of cognitive apprenticeship and an overall learning community (connectivism & constructivism). In module 1, the learning activities include 1 video which focuses on explaining cultural competence and modeling how it looks in authentic, real-world contexts. The two articles list different affective and cognitive competencies from two different subject matter experts. The slide-share was developed as a detailed study guide on the resources provided to students. In module 2, the idea is for students to dive further into connectivism by building an external network outside of the classroom. They will first observe experts on social networks like Facebook and on blogs and then engross themselves in conversations with those experts. Students will seek out peers already working and living abroad, gaining an idea of some of the authentic situations that may arise. 

My team identified the outcomes and strategies on a text-based storyboard. This provided us with the ability to see the module’s resources, learning activities/strategies, and assessments as well as how the course would layout in the LMS.

See the Text-Based Story Board

item.title: CoverPhoto
Overview of Project
item.content:encoded:
Project Overview

Northeastern University will evaluate the current e-Learning and Instructional Design program within the College of Professional Studies. This short-term project will conduct the background research necessary to support a program needs assessment and proposal to update the concentration. This serves as the background work for the business case and the Project Sponsor will utilize the data to propose a curriculum and name change to the e-Learning and Instructional Design program. The sponsor has asked for research into the modern duties of an instructional designer and learning experience designer.

Success Criteria:

This project will be successful if the business case is approved and new development of courses and curricula begins.

This project will be successful if it increases the number of inquiries and enrollments in classes as well as the satisfaction surveys of those enrollees.

This project will be successful if it meets ROI goals and other financial measurements.

This project will be successful if deliverables are completed on time and run professionally according to the project sponsor’s needs.

Project Details:

Project Title:

eLearning and Design Program and Planning Research
Project Dates:

September 29, 2019 to December 8, 2019
Project Coordinators:

Micky M. and Elizabeth G.

item.title: Approach
item.content:encoded:
Approach

As we analyze, our intention is to encode current job descriptions in order to find common key words, themes, competencies, skills, and experience within each description. The focus of our research is to answer the question, “What are current employers looking for in a modern Instructional Designer?”.

We will compile numerical data in order to illustrate the most important competencies, skills, and experience required by employers. We will compile data that illustrates aligned competencies across industry organizations.

We will also analyze other graduate level programs who are offering comparable instructional design and e-learning programs utilizing a SWOT analysis. We will determine if they are meeting the expectations of the current job market. We will look for similarities and differences within the programs as well as niche opportunities that competitive Universities provide for their students. We will compare these programs with that of Northeastern’s and provide recommendations for change.

We will compile this data into comprehensible tables that can be used later in presentations for key stakeholders.

item.title: Project Milestones
item.content:encoded:
Project Tasks

  • Due October 6th

    Research the history of eLearning and Instructional Design and identify a framework for the study. Compile important points into one file.

  • Due Date October 6th

    Project Charter completed and submitted to Sponsor.

  • Due October 13th

    Articulate the Research Problem, Purpose of Study, and Literature Review.

  • Due October 20th

    Create Databases

    Identify variables/categories for industry competencies

    Identify questions for Survey.

    Identify Data Sources (Ex. Students and alumni available to take the survey.)

  • Due October 27th

    Project Management Plan Due to Sponsor

  • Due November 3rd

    Curation of job descriptions from various job boards.

    Input of data into database.

  • Due November 17th

    Research of other University e-Learning and Instructional design programs

    Illustrate University data utilizing SWOT analysis and charts.

  • Due December 1st

    Organization accumulated data from job descriptions, universities, and survey.

    Finalize the visualization of the study.

  • Deliverables are due December 8th

    Write recommendations and findings

    Disseminate Research

item.title: Deliverable #1
item.content:encoded:
Second Deliverable

For the purpose of this course, students should focus on the creation of their own personal or fictional narrative storyline, applying the narrative arc elements of exposition, conflict, rising action, climax, falling action, and resolution. The module can be facilitated as a blended or full face-to-face 3-part learning experience. Each lesson will be a two-hour class session designed to map out the event sequences in narrative stories. Prerequisites from the Common Core Standard, The Common European Framework, and WIDA Standards inform the content as follows:

  • Orient the reader by establishing a situation and introducing a narrator and/or characters; organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally.
  • Use dialogue and description to develop experiences and events or show the responses of characters to situations.
  • Use a variety of transitional words and phrases to manage the sequence of events.
  • Use concrete words and phrases and sensory details to convey experiences and events precisely.
  • Provide a conclusion that follows from the narrated experiences or events.
Lesson Plan
